author: Francesca Gillett
title: Revealed: The seven Tube lines with train seats that never get washed | London Evening Standard
text:
Thursday 23 February 2017 15:27 GMT Click to follow Tube cleaning: The figures come from a Freedom of Information request. PA Archive/PA Images 
Seats on seven Tube lines never get washed with shampoo, surprising new figures have shown. 
Nearly five million people use the London Underground every year but only passengers on three Tube lines are lucky enough to sit on seats which are properly cleaned. 
According to figures from Transport for London, seats on the Bakerloo, Victoria and Central Lines are washed once every six months to a year. 
For the District, Jubilee, Northern, Circle, Piccadilly, Metropolitan and Hammersmith and City Lines, passenger seats are never shampooed. Revealed: the £8bn plan for south-east London's supersized district 
The data was released as part of a Freedom of Information request. 
Despite the lack of a proper shampoo wash, seats are brushed and carriages are given a basic clean every night at the depot. 
The poles which Londoners grip while standing up on the Tube are spot cleaned every night and wiped down every two to three days. 
On the Victoria Line seats are washed every 24 weeks, every 36 weeks on the Bakerloo and at least once a year on the Central. 
Seats on the Jubilee, Northern and Piccadilly Lines are vacuumed and floors are mopped every night. (PA Archive/PA Images) 
Across the rest of the Underground network, floors are mopped at every two to three days. 
TfL spent £8.46 million on cleaning Jubilee, Northern and Piccadilly trains in 2015 and 2016. 
For the Bakerloo, Central, Victoria and Metropolitan, Circle, Hammersmith and City and District Lines, TfL spent £11.61 million on cleaning. 
A spokesperson for Transport for London said: “We’re committed to providing the best possible service on London’s transport network. 
“Although cleaning regimes vary across the Underground, each line has a rigorous cleaning schedule in place, for both the interior and exterior of the trains, to provide a pleasant environment for our customers.” More about:
